div.p: IS a green Oyl, very thick and green; made of green Bay-berries, and Bayleaves. 'Tis brought from Italy.

div.head: Oleum Macis per expreſs.
div.p: OYL of Mace, by expreſſion, ſo called here in England; is nothing elſe but Oyl of Nutmegs by expreſſion; the beſt comes from the Eaſt-Indies: In China jarrs; of a thick Body, a pale Orange colour. There is another ſort brought from Holland in four ſquare Cakes, but nothing near ſo good as the former.

The true Oyl of Mace, by expreſſion, is made in the Eaſt-Indies, out of freſh Mace, and cometh over in Glaſſes and Bottles, being a liquid reddiſh Oyl, ſmelling very ſtrong of the Mace; (and a little ſowriſh) at the bottom a little thicker than above.

div.head: Oleum Macis Com.
div.p: IS a made ſtuff of Sheeps tallow. Palm Oyl, and ſuch like ſtuff coloured, and a little greaſed over with Oyl of Nutmegs, &c. is of little value, and leſs virtue than the aforeſaid.

div.head: Oleum Majorani.
div.p: OYL of ſweet Marjoram, is of a very clear colour, a very little inclining to a red caſt, fragrant ſmell, drawn by Alembick, the Herb being dried firſt.

div.head: Oleum Menthae.
div.p: OYL of Mint, is drawn as the former, of a fragrant ſmell, reſembling the Herb.

div.head: Oleum Nervinum.
div.p: NErve Oyl, is a made thing here by ſome particular People, &c.

div.head: Oleum Nucis Moſchatae
div.p: OYL of Nutmegs, is drawn by Alembick, from Nutmegs; is of a clear Oyl, like Water, of a fragrant ſmell, and hot, grave taſt like Nutmegs.

div.head: Oleum Origani.
div.p:
IS drawn from Origanum, by Diſtillation, and ſometimes off wild Time; of
a dark red Colour, of a ſtrong ſcent, a very ſharp and hot-biting taſt, &c.

div.head: Oleum Palmae.
div.p: IS the product of the Palm-Tree in Guinny, from whence it is brought, of a red, or rather a deep Orange Colour, of a ſweet ſmell; that which is turned White, and Pale Yellowiſh, is decayed.

div.head: Oleum Petroleum.
div.p: IS a fat Liquor, flowing from Rocks, and other Stones in Italy and Sicily: There are two ſorts, the white comes from Parma, the red from Sicily and Italy, &c.

div.head: Oleum Roriſmarini.
div.p: IS an Oyl drawn from Roſemary, by Alembick, is very clear like Water, and of a ſweet ſmell like Roſemary.

div.head: Oleum Scorpionum.
div.p: IS made with Oyl of Almonds, and live Scorpions put into it.

div.head: Oleum Spicae.
div.p: IS an Oyl drawn from Lavender, Roſemary, and other Herbs in France, as they grow together in the Fields, of a ſtrong Smell and clear Colour; it comes from Marſeilles in France.

div.head: Oleum Sabinae.
div.p: OYL of Savine is a Oyl Chymically drawn from the Herb (or rather Shrub) of Sabina, by Diſtilling in it in Water by Alembick, the Oyl being very clear, ſmelling very ſtrong of the ſaid Herb; the Oyl being often imported from Franconia in Germany, wh • re quantities of the ſaid Savine doth grow.

div.head: Oleum Succini
div.p: OYL of Amber is Chymically prepared, by retort out of courſe Amber, being rectified 'tis of a light Amber Colour, of a ſtrong ſmell; the firſt drawing, is a foetid thick Oyl, of a dark Colour.

div.head: Ol • um Sulphuris Com.
div.p: OYL of Sulphur is Chymically drawn from Brimſtone, of a clear Colour, a clear and acid taſte, and in effect, Spirit of Vitriol is every whit as good.

div.head: Oleum Sulphuris per Campan.
div.p: IS Chymically drawn from Brimſtone, the ſame being ſet on fire under a great Glaſs Bell, and gathered in a large Bladder; 'tis of a clear Colour, ſomething inclining to a yellowiſh Colour, of a very acid taſte, and pretty heavy, almoſt without ſmell.

div.head: Oleum Saſſafrae.
div.p: IS drawn from Saſſafraſs-wood, per Alembicum; 'tis of a reddiſh Colour, very hot and heavy, and will ſink under water.

div.head: Oleum Tart • ri Com:
div.p: IS a mixt Oyl of Ol. Tartari, per deliquium and Water.

div.head: Oleum Tartari.
div.p: IS an Oyl made of calcined Tartar, hung in an Hipocratical Sleeve, in a Celler which runs out per deliquium, in a heavy but clear Liquor, ſome-what ſharp and hot in taſte.

div.head: Oleum Thymi.
div.p: OYL of Tyme is drawn from that Herb per Alembicum; of a yellowiſh clear Colour, fragrant ſmell and hot taſt •

div.head: ebinthinae.
div.p: OYL of Turpentine is drawn out of common Turpentine, which comes out of France; 'tis of a clear Body, very hot, penetrating, and of a ſtrong ſmell.

div.head: Oleum Vitrioli.
div.p:
IS an Oyl drawn from calcined Copperas, by a ſtrong Reverberatory Fire, when it is rectified 'tis very clear, of a very heavy Oleaginous Body, very hot,
burning a Pack-Thread to pieces in an inſtant.

div.head: Oleum Myrrhae.
div.p: IS Chymically drawn out of Myrrhae per Retort; 'tis very thick, and of a ſtrong ſmell.

div.head: Opium.
div.p: IS made out of Poppies, being a J • ice boyled up to a Condenſity, ſme ••• ng very ſtrong, of a good lively Colour, cutting eaſily, not hard, being wrapped up in Leaves; the beſt cometh from Aleppo, and Smyrna in Turky; 'tis brought from Surrat and Perſia, in the Eaſt-Indi • s; but is far inferiour in quality, being nothing near ſo clean, nor of ſo ſtrong a ſmell, as the Turky ſort.

div.head: Opobalſamum.
div.p: SEE Balſam Judaicum, Balſam Gilead, &c. being nothing elſe.

div.head: Os Sepiae.
div.p: CUttle-bones, is called by the Germans, the Scum of the Seas, being in effect, nothing elſe but a White Scummy Subſtance, and theſe are found here in England in Suſſex, and near the Iſle of Wight, and other parts on the Sea▪ſhoar, thoſe which are large, long, broad, and well dryed, are beſt, they are much ſold by theſe Ironmongers, which ſell Tools to Silver-Smiths and Gold-Smiths.

div.head: Os de Corde Cervi.
div.p: THE Bone out of the Heart of a Stag, is a Bone found in the Hearts of Stags, almoſt reſembling a Croſs, but ſome more than others, being a little flat bone, and to be had in any part of Europe, eſpecially, if they uſe thoſe of an Ox inſtead of it.

div.head: Piper Album.
div.p: WHite Pepper, is made from the largeſt black Pepper, by art; being very full, round, large and white. Some has been made here in England, but not ſo good.

div.head: Piper Guineae.
div.p: GUinea Pepper, is improperly ſo called, not any coming from thence, but from Marſeilles: That which is in lively red Cods, not broken, and freſh, is to be preferred.

div.head: Piper longum.
div.p: LOng Pepper, cometh to us from the Eaſt-Indies: The larger, and white within, bright without, is the beſt.

div.head: Piper Nigrum.
div.p: BLack Pepper, is more of uſe to Grocers and Druggiſts. The beſt and largeſt, is your Malabar Pepper, being heavy, and of a good ſubſtance.

div.head: Pix Burgundica.
div.p: BUrgundy Pitch, comes from a certain kind of Firr-tree, near Strasbourgh: That which is ſoft, and of a bright colour, is beſt.

div.head: Pix Liquida.
div.p: SOft Pitch, is a made thing by the Shoomakers, and of little uſe amongſt the Druggiſts.

div.head: Pix Navalis.
div.p: IS a ſoftiſh Pitch, which cometh from Godenburgh, and other places of Sweeden; having its name (Ship-Pitch) becauſe great quantities are uſed in building of Ships.

div.head: Pix Sicca.
div.p: IS the very ſame as Ship Pitch, as aforeſaid, being only boyled to a dryneſs or hardneſs; and therefore called dry Pitch, becauſe the other is liquid and running.

div.head: Plumbum Album.
div.p: SEE Ceruſſa, both being one and the ſame; except ſome that are papered over, others are not; which go by the Name of white Lead.

div.head: Plumbum Nigrum.
div.p: THE beſt black Lead is found here in England, in black Lead Mines; ſoft, and of a firm body, not rocky, ſmooth, in pieces of ſeveral bigneſs. There comes a ſort from Spain, and although it be ſoft, yet 'tis ſubject to be brittle, and break in ſmall pieces, and Powder, that nothing can be made out of it. Another ſort coming from the Weſt-Ind • es, is courſer and rocky, of little uſe and value.

div.head: Plumbum Rubrum.
div.p: RED Lead is made here in England, in Darbyſhire, in great quantities; and from thence Tranſported to moſt parts of Europe; being of a red colour, the next to Vermilion, of a heavy body.

div.head: Plumbum Uſtum.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation (which is called Caementatoria) of Lead, which is made with Powder of Brimſtone, and the Scales of Lead, which being thus burned, is often waſhed; and thus becomes the Plumbum Uſtum, which is uſed.

div.head: Polium Montanum.
div.p: IS an Herb which groweth in Sicily, Italy, and Spain, being covered over with a downe of a lively freſh ſmell, and greeniſh Colour.

div.head: Pompholyx,
div.p:
OR Nihil Album, having its name from its fine and pure white Colour; 'tis ſaid to be gathered of a Fume which
riſes from Metal (in the fuſion of it) being white and fine, but nothing near ſo heavyas white Lead. It is brought out of Germany.

div.head: Priapus Cervi.
div.p: IS the Piſle of a Hart or Stag dry'dup, of a reddiſh brown Colour.

div.head: Priapus Equi Marini.
div.p: A Sea-horſe Piſle is of a bony ſubſtance like Ivory, ſome above half a yard in length, thick at the fore part (or Glans) and running ſmaller at the hind part. They are brought from Greenland, and other parts of the Weſt-Indies.

div.head: Priapus Tauri.
div.p: 'TIS the Piſle of a Bull, almoſt a yard long, dryed up in the Sun.

div.head: Priapus Turturis Marini.
div.p: 'TIS the Piſle of a Sea Turtel, dryed up, is a quarter of a yard long.

div.head: Pulmo Vulpis.
div.p: 'TIS the Lungs of a Fox dryed, of a ſtrong ſmell; the neweſt, freſheſt and ſoundeſt are to be preferred.

div.head: Pulvis Curcumae.
div.p: POwder of Turmerick is ground in a Mill, of a fine lively reddiſh Orange Colour; being free from all other mixtures, ſmelling ſtrong of Cucurma.

div.head: Pulvis Enulae Campan.
div.p: ELecampane Powder, is ground as aforeſaid, the Roots being well dryed firſt; of a good ſmell, reſembling Elecampane.

div.head: Pulvis Glycyrrhizae.
div.p: LIquoriſh Powder, is grounded out of Spaniſh Liquoriſh, of a pale yellowiſh Colour, and a ſtrong taſte of the Liquoriſh, 'tis adulterated with Flower, whichmay be diſtinguiſhed in the taſt, &c.

div.head: Pulvis Santali Rubri.
div.p: POwder of red Sanders, is ground by a Mill, of a fine lively red colour. 'Tis uſed therefore, more in Dying than Phyſical Uſes.

div.head: Radix Acori.
div.p: OF which the trueſt is reckoned to be the Calamus Aromaticus; but amongſt us here in England it is a Root which comes from the Eaſt-Indies, much reſembling Galanga major, being larger, more dark of colour without, and whiter within; not ſo Aromatick, or fragrant in taſt, as Galanga minor.

div.head: Radix Alcannae.
div.p:
ALkanet Root, is of a dark red colour, and white within; that which is ſo the moſt part red, very thin, and not woody, is beſt eſteemed. They
are brought out of France, Italy, and ſome out of Holland.

div.head: Radix Angelicae.
div.p: ANgelica Root, is a longiſh Root, a large thick Head; a great many ſmall Roots (or large and long Vipers) of above half a foot in length, of a good odoriferous ſmell, a hot Aromatick taſt; the Root is flexible (if new) breaks white within. They are ſometimes mixt with Meum Roots, which break of a brown yellowiſh within. They come from Germany.

div.head: Radix Ariſtolochiae Long.
div.p: LOng Ariſtolochia Roots come to us out of France by the way of Marſcilles; being a long thickiſh Root, cuts white, a little inclining to a yellowiſh colour within. Thoſe which are freſh, are to be preferred.

div.head: Radix Ariſtolochiae Rotundae.
div.p:
ROund Ariſtolochia Roots, are of a round ſhape, much like the foreſaid
Roots; coming likewiſe the ſame way, &c.

div.head: Radix Aſari.
div.p: ASarum Root, is a ſmall (Aſh-coloured) Root, long fibers; of a pretty ſmell, and aromatick and hot taſt. They are likewiſe brought from Germany.

div.head: Radix Behen Albi.
div.p: IS a longiſh whitiſh Root, not unlike to wild Parſnips, but thinner. It groweth in Italy, Germany, and France, &c.

div.head: Radix Behen Rubri.
div.p: IS a dark reddiſh, brown coloured Root; in round rowles or ſlices, like Jallop: It grows as above.

div.head: Radix Biſtortae.
div.p: SO called from its crooked bending together; it is likewiſe called the larger Snake Weed, of a whitiſh colour when ſcraped: It grows here in England and Germany, &c.

div.head: Radix Calami Aromatici.
div.p: 'TIs a ſweet ſcented Root, fragrant, hot, and ſomewhat bitteriſh in taſt; it breaks white, and is a little knotty as it were. It is brought in Quantities from Germany.

div.head: * Radix Chinae Optimae.
div.p: CHina Roots, the beſt being large, well fed, and firm; cut white and bright within, and light brown without; free from Worms. They come from Rantam and China, in the Eaſt-Indies.

div.head: * Radix Chinae Nodoſae.
div.p: FLinty China Roots are heavy, and not eaſily to be broken or cut, becauſe of a reſiny flinty Subſtance, which is black, like that of reſiny Jallop.

div.head: * Radix Contrayervae.
div.p:
COntrayerva Roots are of a lively yellowiſh colour, inclining to red; of an inch long, or more, full of little ſmall Vipers round about them; of a good pleaſant
ſmell, and white within. They come from the Spaniſh Weſt-Indies.

div.head: * Radix Coſti Amari.
div.p: IN the Apothecaries Shops, there is ſweet and bitter Coſtus, being both of one Species; the neweſt being ſweet, and with Age grow bitter. That which is to be choſen, ought to be of an Aſh colour without, and white within, being freſh, of a firm body and well ſcented.

div.head: * Radix Coſti Dulcis.
div.p: AS what we have ſaid to Coſtus Amarus, it is the neweſt and freſheſt of Coſtus, &c.

div.head: * Radix Curcumae.
div.p:
TUrmerick, Terra merita, is a Root which is brought from the Eaſt Indies. There are two ſorts; one long, which is pure and fine, called the Perſian ſort; breaks not only of a fine yellow, but gives alſo a Tincture like Saffron: The other ſort is ſhorter and rounder, of a yellow green without▪ That which
is firm, of a lively colour in breaking, and looks not black, is the beſt.

div.head: * Radix Cyperi Longi.
div.p: IS a long, dark, reddiſh Root, full of little knots or ſpecks; breaking white within, of a pleaſant •• ell; 'tis uſed in Perfumes, ſweet Powder, &c. It groweth here in England.

div.head: Radix Cyperi Rotund.
div.p: IS a round reddiſh Root, coming from Turky, out of Syria, Italy, and Alexandria; 'tis eſteemed better for vertue than the long Cypreſs Roots. That which is well fed, firm, and hard to be broken, of a pleaſant acriminous ſmell, is to be preferred.

div.head: Radix Dictamni Alb.
div.p: IS a thin whitiſh Root, of a bitteriſh and glutenous taſt. The beſt is gathered in Winter, and cometh to us from Germany.

div.head: Radix Doronici Rom.
div.p: DOronicum, is (a kind of a Wolf-Bane) a little ſmall knobby Root, firm, light, brown without, and white within. 'Tis brought from Germany; it groweth in Auſtria, Styria and Helvetia.

div.head: Radix Ellebori Alb.
div.p: WHite Hellebore (or Sneeſe Root) is a round, ſhort, knobby Root. It comes from Germany; a little of it being ſcraped in Powder, will cauſe a violent ſneeſing.

div.head: Radix Ellebori Nigri.
div.p: BLack Hellebore, is a ſmall, black, viperous Root; breaketh (if good) white within. 'Tis brought in bundles from Germany.

div.head: Radix Enulae Campanae.
div.p: ELecampane Roots, grow here in England, Germany, and other parts in Europe; of a bitteriſh taſt, and a pale yellowiſh colour, inclining to white.

div.head: Radix Eryngii.
div.p: ERingo Roots, Sea-holm, or Sea-holly▪ Roots, a great deal of them are brought from France. It groweth likewiſe in Germany, England, and other places in Europe; 'tis preſerved in Confects, which are very white and delicious.

div.head: Radix Galangae.
div.p: GAlanga Minor, cometh from the Eaſt-Indies. 'Tis cut in little pieces, a browniſh red Coat, and pale red within, of a hot aromatick taſt and ſmell.

div.head: Radix Gentianae.
div.p: GEntian Roots, is of a bitter taſte, a dark yellow colour within; of a large bigneſs, (not ſlit, which is looked upon the worſt) well fed, firm, breaking clear and bright within. It cometh out of Germany in great Quantities.

div.head: Radix Glycyrrhizae Angl.
div.p:
ENgliſh Liquorish, groweth here about this City, and in Yorkſhire plentifully;
being good, 'tis large, thick, well fed, cuts bright within, and is of a good length. It groweth in moſt parts of Europe.

div.head: Radix Glycyrrhizae Hiſpan.
div.p: SPaniſh Liquoriſh, is brought over to us; being dry, of a bright colour within, and not blackiſh.

div.head: Radix Hermodactyli.
div.p: 'TIs a Root of the bigneſs of a Cheſnut, white without, and within: They are choſen large, heavy, firm, not Worm eaten; being beaten, will reduce into a Powder, like Flower, of a ſweet taſt. They come from Syria, and ſome parts of Italy.

div.head: * Radix Jalappae.
div.p: JAllop, is a Root which cometh from the Spaniſh Weſt-Indies, being cut in ſlices, and dryed; of which are two ſorts, white and black; of which, the black being reſinous, is to be preferred: The larger and the heavier, the better; the white is not ſo good, eſpecially Wormeaten.

div.head: Radix Iridis Florent.
div.p: FLorentine Orris, cometh from Italy; the beſt being very white, full, round, of a ſtrong fragrant ſmell, like Violets.

div.head: Radix Mechoacannae.
div.p: MEcoacan Roots, is a Root which cometh from the Spaniſh Weſt-Indies; being very white, ſhrinking a little. 'Tis in pieces a great deal larger than Jallop.

div.head: Radix Mei Athamant.
div.p: MEum Roots; the beſt groweth in Germany; is a ſingle Root, bearded at the Head, of a fragrant ſmell: Thoſe which are gathered here in England, are full bearded, and the Root not ſo large.

div.head: Radix Peoniae Maris.
div.p:
THE greater Piony, or the Male Piony, is a reddiſh Root, round and • hick, of no great Conſumption to the Druggiſt, being a thing very ſeldom uſed.
They grow in England, and moſt parts.

div.head: Radix Phu Majoris.
div.p: PHU the great, cometh from Germany; 'tis by ſome called Garden Valerian: It groweth likewiſe in England.

div.head: Radix Polypodii Querc.
div.p: POlypody, is called by ſome, many Feet, or Fern; that of the Oak (being an Excreſcence) is the beſt. 'Tis found in England, Germany, &c. That which breaks green within, and dark coloured without, is beſt.

div.head: Radix Pyrethri.
div.p: PEllitory of Spain, is a very hot Root, breaks whitiſh within: That which comes from Italy and the Straits, is thicker and ſhorter than that which cometh out of Germany, where it is called Tooth-Root.

div.head: * Radix Rhabarbari.
div.p: THE beſt of all Rubarbs is brought to us from Turky; ('tis ſaid to grow in Tartary) of fine midling pieces, ſmooth, and not cruſty, freſh coloured, a lively ſtrong ſmell, cutting firm; (in chawing ſomewhat bitteriſh, and aſtringent in taſt) of a freſh yellowiſh colour, a fragrant Flavour; not too heavy, nor cruſty, nor hollow, or rotten within. The Ruſſia Rubarb is the next to it, which is generally large and heavy, and more cruſty; though ſometimes very freſh, and well ſcented, but nothing near ſo fine as there came lately from the Eaſt-Indies: And though it be never ſo good in the Country, yet in the bringing over, it loſeth its ſmell and goodneſs, by the extream Heat of the Sun, turning black and hard within, which is of little value.

div.head: * Radix Rapontici.
div.p: RAponticum cometh from Ruſſia, as alſo from the Straits; that which is of a freſh colour, inclining to yellow and red, is the beſt, and the nearer it cometh to Rubarb.

div.head: Radix Rubiae Tinctorum.
div.p: MAdder Roots are made here in England, at Wiſbitch, in the Iſle of Ely, and a great deal in Zealand. The largeſt and biggeſt, are preferred, being of a good reddiſh colour.

div.head: * Radix Sarſaparillae.
div.p: SArſaparilla, is brought to us from the the Spaniſh Weſt-Indies, is more like long Weed than a Root; if good, very round, well fed, full, mealy, and white within, (if cut) the hungry, and lean, is nothing near ſo good. There is a wild Sarſaparilla which cometh from Jam •• c • , which is large, but not mealy, rather woody and ſtalky; it is worth little to the former. They come in round Collars and long Bundles, and are (I mean the beſt in Collars) brought to us from Spain.

div.head: Radix Serpentariae Virg.
div.p:
VIrginy Snack Root, is a ſmall viperous Root, of a ſtrong, hot, aromatical taſt, of a Parſnip colour: 'Tis
brought from Virginia; the goodneſs is known by the ſmell and cleanneſs, being free from Sand or Duſt.

div.head: Radix Sciilae.
div.p: SQuills, are a ſort of Sea Onions, of a large and great bigneſs: There are two ſorts, viz. red and white: Thoſe which are dry and ſound are to be preferred. They grow in Apulia, Portugal, • i • ily, and other places; from whence •• ey are brought to us.

div.head: Radix Scorzonerae.
div.p: SCorcionera Roots, are brought to us from Germany: Thoſe which are large, freſh coloured, a yellowiſh red without, and white within, are beſt.

div.head: Radix Thapſiae.
div.p: THapſie Turpith, is much like unto white Dictamus Roots, &c. like the ſmalleſt Winter Bark, whitiſh; it is of • ittle uſe, and is brought from the Eaſt-Indies and the Straits.

div.head: Radix Tormentillae.
div.p: TOrmentill Roots grow here in England, Germany, France, and moſt parts of Europe.

div.head: Radix Turpethi.
div.p: OF Turpith there are two ſorts; the beſt is that which is brought from Turky, called Turpethum Alexandrinum and Arabum, thoſe being places of its growth, it is large and gummy: That which comes from the Eaſt-Indies, is nothing near ſo good.

div.head: Radix Zedoariae.
div.p: TWO ſorts are likewiſe of Zedoaria, the long and the round, both being of a white colour, ſtrong ſmell and taſt, ſomewhat near reſembling Ginger. It is brought from Turky, and like to grow in Synnea, and the further parts of the East-Indies.

div.head: Radix Zinziberis.
div.p: GInger, of this the white and black; the white is generally the beſt eſteemed; great Quantities come from Barbadoes and other parts of the Weſt-Indies; and there is likewiſe a great deal in the Eaſt Indies, but moſt which is brought from thence, is confited or green Ginger.

div.head: Reſina Pinca.
div.p: THe Roſin of a Pine-tree, is like common Roſin, of very little uſe.

div.head: Reſina Jalapii.
div.p: ROſin of Jallop is of a Chymical Preparation, the ſame being drawn from a good black roſiny Jallop; its goodneſs is known by being clear, tranſparent in a manner.

div.head: Reſina Scammonii.
div.p: ROſin of Scamony is likewiſe drawn from Scamony, in a Chymical way, as the Roſin of Jallop, aforeſaid.

div.head: Sal Abſinthii.
div.p: SALT of Wormwood is Chimically made of Wormwood, being calcined very dry and white is the beſt.

div.head: Sal Artemiſiae.
div.p: IS a Chimical Salt made of Mug • vort, by calcining, filtring, &c.

div.head: Sal Ammoniacum.
div.p: OF which there is two ſorts, the Potlid ſort, and the Sugar Loaf ſort; the beſt is clear and white; the former, which comes from Turkey, and the latter which comes from the Eaſt-Indies, is the worſt ſort.

div.head: Sal Chalybis.
div.p: OR Salt of Steel, is a Chimical Preparation made here in England, &c.

div.head: Sal Cardui.
div.p: IS likewiſe Chimically made of the bleſſed Thiſtle, by burning it to Aſhes, calcining and filtring, and rendring it to a Salt, which has very little of the taſte of Carduus.

div.head: Sal Cochleariae.
div.p: SAlt of Scurvey graſs is Chimically made, as that of Wormwood, and therefore much like it.

div.head: Sal Eupatorij.
div.p: IS likewiſe Chymically made, from the ſaid Herb, as the other Salt aforeſaid.

div.head: Sal Gemmae.
div.p: ALias Sal Foſſile, is a Salt which is in ſtony pieces, like pieces of Cryſtal, almoſt tranſparent, breaking in four ſquare pieces; that which is clear and clean is the beſt. It comes from Dantzick, Italy and France.

div.head: Sal Geniſtae.
div.p: IS Chymically made from Broom, as Salt of Wormwood, &c. aforeſaid.

div.head: Sal Nitrum.
div.p: SAlt Petre, is a ſulphureous Salt drawn out of the Earth; the beſt is that which will eaſily be ſet on Fire, and which is well refined, clear and tranſparant, in lumps and roches: The greateſt part comes from the Eaſt-India's; ſome little may be drawn out of Stables, Cellars, and other places.

div.head: Sal Prunellae, or Lapis Prunellae
div.p: IS nothing elſe but a refined Salt Peter, melted down and caſt in Cakes, &c. in a Chymical way with Flos Sulphur.

div.head: Sal Succini.
div.p:
SAlt of Amber; is a volatile Salt which comes over in the drawing of the Oyl of Amber; the ſaid Salt playing up, and ſticking faſt to the Neck of the Retort,
from whence it is taken and prepared 'tis of an Acid Taſt, and if well refined will be whitiſh.

div.head: Sal Tartari.
div.p: SAlt of Tartar, is Chymically made of Argol, &c.

div.head: Sael Vitrioli.
div.p: SAlt of Vitriol is Chymically drawn from White Copperas, off the Caput Mortum of Vitriol.

div.head: Saccharum Saturni.
div.p: SUgar of Lead is made by a Chymical way from white Lead and Diſtilled Vinegar: The beſt is light whitiſh, in long Flakes:

div.head: Saccharum Cand Alb.
div.p: WHite Sugar Candy is made by the Sugar Bakers here in England, and moſt parts of Europe; the cleaneſt and whitiſt is to be prefered.

div.head: Sanguis Draconis.
div.p: DRagons Blood is brought from Bantam in the Eaſt-India's: 'Tis the Juice of a Tree, whoſe Fruit is red like a Cherry; ſome of it is extraordinary fine, which comes in Drops wrapp'd up in Flags; others in round large Rowls, covered over with Flags; the courſer is in Lumps: the goodneſs is known by its fine red Colour, when ſtruck upon white Paper.

div.head: Sanguis Hirci.
div.p: IS the Blood of a Young Goat, dryed up, &c.

div.head: Scinci Marini.
div.p: ARe Creatures with four Legs, a Head and a Tail, like an Eft; they ſwim in Ponds, and feed upon odoriferous Herbs. They are ſent over dryed up and ſalted; thoſe which are large, not broken, dry and freſh Coloured are the beſt. They come from Venice.

div.head: Scorpiones Terreſtres.
div.p: SCorpions are a kind of a Venomous Worm or Inſect, much reſembling a Cray-Fiſh, with his Tail having a ſharp Sting bended like a Claw. They are ſometimes brought over alive from Germany, otherwiſe they are dryed. The largeſt are beſt, but the live ones are reckoned far better.

div.head: Serieum Crudum.
div.p: IS the Bag, or the ſilken Pouches of the Silk-worm, which the Silk-worm ſpins the Silk upon. They are to be had in all places from whence Silk uſes to come; being about the bigneſs of a Birds Egg, and ſome bigger.

div.head: Sevum Cervinum.
div.p: STags, or Deers Tallow, is made in Enggland, and all parts of Europe; being very hard and white, of a ſweet ſmell if freſh.

div.head: Courteous Reader.
div.p: THE Intent of this Book was chiefly to know the place of Growth of moſt Drugs, being thereto deſired by an intire Friend of mine. The Deſcription, and of the quality of every Drug is difficult enough, but would be more in the Seeds; which cannot well be ſhown but by Eye-ſight: Therefore I have only to all thoſe ſeveral Seeds, which come from beyond the Sea, ſet the places from whence they are brought.

div.head: * Scammonium.
div.p: IS the Juice of the Roots of Scamony, which is full of a Milky Juice, which is thickned and made up in old Boots. The beſt of it comes from Aleppo, being clean, free from Sand and Droſs, ſhining like Roſin, breaking eaſily, and if touch'd with the Tongue, turning white like Milk.
The Scamony which comes from Smyrna, is generally not ſo fine as the Aleppo, being heavy, more droſſie, and ſometimes full of Duſt and Sand.

div.head: Sperma Coeti.
div.p: IS ſaid to be the Seed of a Whale: There has been Sperma Coeti Whales caught upon the Coaſt of Ireland, but more commonly 'tis found in a dead Whales Head near Bermoodos. The Sperma Coeti, is to be choſen very white, as Snow, in large and great Flakes, not oyly, or diſcoloured, nor of a ſtrong ſmell.

div.head: Spiritus Salis Ammon.
div.p: SPirit Sal-Ammoniack, is Chymically drawn from the Sal Ammoniack, &c. which being very clear, like Rock Water; but of a moſt ſtrong volatil Spirit, enough to ſtrike any Man's breath in ſmelling to a Quantity.

div.head: Spiritus ſalis Com.
div.p: SPirit of Salt is likewiſe Chymically drawn from Bay Salt, of an Acid taſt: The beſt is heavy, and of an Amber colour.

div.head: Spiritus Mellis.
div.p: THE Spirit of Honey is Chymically drawn from Honey, by Retort.

div.head: Spiritus Vitrioli.
div.p: IS likewiſe Chymically drawn from Copperas, &c.

div.head: Spiritus Cornu Cervi.
div.p: IS drawn from Harts-horn: The Oyl being ſeparated, and the ſpirit rectified, is as clear as Cryſtal.

div.head: Spiritus Cochleariae.
div.p: IS alſo Chymically drawn from Scurvy-Graſs, and Spirit of Wine; taſting very ſtrong of the Scrvy-Graſs; and as clear as Water.

div.head: Spiritus Abſinthii.
div.p: IS drawn Chymically from Wormwood, &c.

div.head: Spiritus Sulphuris.
div.p: IS likewiſe drawn from Brimſtone, by Retort.

div.head: Spica Nardi Indicae.
div.p:
IS a kind of a Root which comes from the Eaſt-Indies; of a fragrant, ſtrong ſmell, and as it were hairy: That which is light, long, and ſhort haired, is to be
choſen; of a yellow colour, inclining to a red, of a bitter taſt, ſticking to the Tongue.

div.head: * Spica Nardi Celticae.
div.p: CEltick Spicknard, is a kind of Flowers made up in bundles; the leaves of a bright yellow, ſomewhat reſembling Marigold-flowers, of a ſtrong fragrant ſmell, being free from Sand and Duſt, and full of ſmall Roots.

div.head: Spongia.
div.p: SPunges grow under Water, at the ſide of Rocks; The greateſt part are brought to us from Smyrna and Aleppo, and other plaees in Turkey. Thoſe which are fine feel ſmooth and cloſe, not too full of large Holes: They are ſaid to grow moſt in the Archipelago. Thoſe which are large, fine, cloſe and lively coloured, either white or yellow, are to be preferred.

div.head: Sebeſten.
div.p:
IS a Fruit of a Tree much like unto a ſmall Prune, the ſtone within almoſt
four-ſquare, of a black colour; they are to be choſen: Thoſe which are freſh, plump, full of Meat, and moiſt; they are imported from Italy. They grow likewiſe in Syria and Egypt.

div.head: Styrax Liquida.
div.p: LIquid Styrax, is a fat liquor, as thick as many Balſam; of a ſtrong and fragrant ſmell, if clear and good, of a whitiſh colour: 'Tis kept in Water becauſe of its clammineſs. The ſame comes from the Straits.

div.head: Succus Acacia.
div.p: IS the Juice of a Thorny Fruit called Acacia, growing in Egypt; out of its Seeds the true Acacia is made by Expreſſion; the colour not ſo black, but more inclining to a red, which above all other, is to be preferred in making of Venice Treacle. The Acacia now in uſe, is made of Sloes in Germany, and brought over in round Balls, wrapp'd up in Bladders. The goodneſs is known by its ſharp Reſtringency.

div.head: Succus Liquiritiae Angl.
div.p: ENgliſh Juice of Liquoriſh, is made in round Balls and ſealed; it is generally made up with old Prunes, Liquoriſh, and ſuch other Trumperies, and therefore far inferiour to the Spaniſh Juice.

div.head: Succus Glycyrrhizae Hiſp.
div.p: SPaniſh Juice of Liquoriſh, is made by boyling the Juice to a Condenſity, to make it up in Rolls and Cakes, wrapt up in Bay-leaves: The beſt breaks freely and clear, ſhining like Jet, free from being burnt to. 'Tis brought out of Italy.

div.head: Succus Hypociſtis.
div.p: IS the Juice of a Plant, being preſſed out when in its Flowers, and dried up in the Sun, and not unlike to Juice of Liquoriſh; being brought from Italy and Germany.

div.head: Succus Kermes.
div.p:
JUice of Alkermes, is made of Alkermes Berries, &c. and brought over from
Marſeilles, being of a bright Scarlet colour, well reliſhed and taſted, of an acid taſt, and a good Body.

div.head: Sulphur Vivum.
div.p: OR live Brimſtone, is nothing elſe but Brimſtone, before Fuſion, of a grayiſh colour, and acid taſt; and not ſo eaſie to take fire, as other Brimſtone, It is brought to us from Italy.

div.head: Talcum Com.
div.p: COmmon Tale looks red without, and white within: There is a great deal to be had in Germany, and in Yorkſhire, here in England.

div.head: Talcum Venetum.
div.p:
VEnetian Talk, is a Stone which ſhines, of ſeveral colours, as it were of Gold, Silver and green; and therefore by ſome called the Star of the Earth; yet it will
come off in Shivers: 'Tis brought to us from Italy.

div.head: * Tamarindi.
div.p: IS the Fruit of a ſmall Shrub in the Eaſt-Indies, growing like Aſh-keys. The beſt is reckoned to be the red, of a lively, ſharp, accid taſt; others like the black ſort better; thoſe which are leaſt ſtony and ſtringy, are to be preferred: They come from the Eaſt-Indies.

div.head: Tartarum Album.
div.p: WHite Argol, or Rheniſh Argol, the beſt is that which comes from Heylbron and Strasbourg breaking clear, and free, without Droſs: It is brought out of Germany.

div.head: Tartarum Rubruns.
div.p: REd Argol is very courſe: 'Tis brought to us from Genoua, Florence, and ſome parts of France.

div.head: Tartarum Vitriclatum.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation made out of Oyl of Tartar, per Deliquium, and Oyl of Vitriol.

div.head: * Tea.
div.p: IS a ſmall Herb of a Shrub which grows in China; the ſame is uſed in moſt Coffee-Houſes: The goodneſs conſiſts of a fine green Tenderneſs, excellent fragrant ſmell, like Violet, and to keep a good, clear, and green colour in the Water; being chewed, ſtreaks very green like Graſs; of it are ſeveral ſorts which muſt be diſtinguiſhed by the Eye, taſt and ſmell, above all the leaves, fine, criſp'd, green, inclining to Razor-blew-colour.

div.head: Terra Sigillata Alb.
div.p: IS a thing made out of fine Earth, and ſealed here in England.

div.head: Terra Sigi •••• a Rubr.
div.p:
IS likewiſe made here, •• d ſ •• led; their goodneſs are according to what Earth
is uſed in the making up of them.

div.head: Terra Lemnia.
div.p: IS a fattiſh red Earth, coming from Turky, by ſome called Axungia Solis, this is a fatter Earth, and darker red, than the fine Bole; the goodneſs of it conſiſts, if thrown into Water, to riſe up in Bubbles, if touched by the Tongue, to adhere to it.

div.head: Terra Sigillata V • ra.
div.p: USED to be brought out of Turky, ſealed with Turkiſh Characters; but of late ſeveral Fallacies being diſcovered, there is a Sealed Earth made out of Terra Lemnia; and ſome ſealed Earths are brought from Germany, growing near Strigonia, which is by modern Phyſicians beſt eſteemed.

div.head: * Terra Japonica, alias Catechu.
div.p: IS a dark colour'd Earth, like to courſe Aloes Socatrina; if chewed, it diſſolves, taſtes adſtringent in the Mouth, and ſweet in the Throat: 'Tis brought from the Eaſt-Indies.

div.head: Terra Samia.
div.p: IS an Earth which comes from Armenia, growing near a City called Samos: 'Tis adſtringent, and of a yellowiſh colour.

div.head: Terebinthina Com.
div.p: IS brought to us in great Abundance from France, from whence the Oyl of Turpentine is drawn in Quantities, and little Barrels of ſeveral Weights, are made up for the Druggiſts uſe: 'Tis of a thick Body, ſtrong ſmell, and whitiſh colour.

div.head: Terebenthina Veneta.
div.p: VEnetian Turpentine, is of a thin, clear, tranſparent Body, and indifferently well ſcented: 'Tis brought from thence, and ſome parts of Germany, as Brechmen, being brought down from Salzburgh and N • rimburgh, &c.

div.head: Terebenthina Strasb.
div.p:
IS of a green, and inclining to an Amber colour; very clear, well ſcented,
and brought from Strasbourgh.

div.head: * Terebinthina Cypria.
div.p: IS brought to us in Gourds; ſomething reſembling Chio Turpentine, but that it is generally foul, and full of Droſs, and a thicker body than any other.

div.head: * Terebinthina è Chio.
div.p: CHio Turpentine, comes over from Turkey in earthen Pots, is very clear and thick, of a yellowiſh colour.

div.head: Tincal.
div.p: IS nothing elſe but an unrefined Borax, brought over to us in Tuppers, from the Eaſt-Indies: The beſt, is that which is in large greeniſh pieces, free from Mud, (which it is generally peſtered with) as alſo, ſmall Pibble ſtones) and greaſed over with ſtinking Oyl, which is ſaid to be Neats-foot Oyl. The drieſt, cleaneſt, and largeſt is therefore to be preferred.

div.head: Trochiſci de Viperis,
div.p: 'TIs a little round Cake, made and ſealed, with the Mucilage of the Powder of Vipers, and beaten Biskets, and dryed in the Sun. The beſt come from Venice.

div.head: Turneſole.
div.p: ARE nothing but old Rags, and Linnon dipped in the red juice of Grapes, (others ſay in Mulberry juice) and dried up in the Sun: They ſtrike a red colour in White-Wine, or other Water, like Claret. They come to us out of France.

div.head: THUS.
div.p: FRankincenſe, is brought to us from France, in large pieces; that which is beſt, is in large, dry and white pieces.

div.head: Viſcus Quercinus.
div.p: THE beſt of Miſſeltoes; are found upon large Oaks, almoſt the colour of the ſame; other Miſſels are found upon Apple Trees, and others; but not ſo good.

div.head: Viſcus Aucupum.
div.p: OR Bird-Lime, is a thing made here in England, with which Nut-Oyl being ſtruck over little Rods, is ſo clammy, that it faſteneth the ſmall Birds to it.

div.head: Vitriolum Album.
div.p: VVHite Cop • eras comes to us from Hamborow; that in large and great Pigs, white, and not yellow nor duſty, is looked upon the beſt.

div.head: Vi • riolum Viride.
div.p: GReen Copperas is made in great quantities here in England, from a round Stone which is found in the Iſle of Wight, and old-ruſty Iron.

div.head: Vitriolum Dantz.
div.p: IS made in Pruſſia; the ſame running more upon Copper: This is looked upon better than Engliſh.

div.head: Vitriolum Hungariae.
div.p: THE Hungarian Vitriol, is of a blewiſh green colour: 'Tis ſaid to grow near Silver, Gold and Copper: Several Counterfeits are ſold for it.

div.head: Vitriolum Roman.
div.p: ROman Vitriol, is vulgarly ſo called, it is nothing elſe but Cypreſs Vitrio, in cut Stones, very blew like a Sapphire. There is another ſort which comes in Duppers from the Eaſt Indies, not inferiour to the former, but that it generally runs together in lumps, and not looſe, nor in cut Stones.

div.head: Ungula Alcis.
div.p: ELks claws, come to us from Dantzick. The beſt are thoſe which are large, full Legs to the upper Knuckle, full Hooff'd, and well Haired.

div.head: Unguent Flor. Aurant.
div.p: ORange Flower Butter is made from the Orange Flower, and if right, with Pomatum. The beſt comes from Bermoodos; ſome good comes from France and Genoua.

div.head: Uſnea Cranii Humani.
div.p: THE Moſs of a Scull of any dead • ody dying violently, and left unburied in the Field, we have ſeen it in ſome Sculls brought from Ireland.

div.head: Zibethum, or Civet.
div.p:
THE beſt of it is reckoned to be made in England, though a great deal more
is made in Holland, and with Certificates Tranſported into moſt parts of Europe. That which is clear, of a fine, lively, whitiſh colour, not mixt with Butter, &c. is to be preferred. The African, Barbados, and other Civets coming from the Weſt-Indies, are next to it: But that blackiſh ſort which comes from the Eaſt-Indies, is by none which underſtands any, looked upon as any thing.

div.head: Zinziber Condit.
div.p: GReen Ginger is brought from ſeveral parts into England, as from the Eaſt-Indies, Weſt-Indies, and of late, a great deal from Barbados. That which is clear, large, not ſtringy, is the beſt.

div.head: Zylobalſamum.
div.p: SEE Lignum Lentiſcinum, being the ſame.

div.head: CATALOGUS Pharmacorum omnium quae apud PHARMACOPOLAS LONDINENSES Venalia Proſtant.
BOOKS Printed for, and Sold by John Harris, at the Harrow againſt the Church in the Poultrry: And Tho. Howkins, in George-Yard, in Lombard-ſtreet.
div.p:
THere is now in the Preſs, and will ſpeedily be Publiſhed, a very Excellent and Uſeful Book; being curious Receipts in Phyſick and Chyrurgery: By Van Helmon •
and Paracelſus, that famous Phyſician and Philoſopher: Wherein is contained, the proper Medecines for all Diſtempers incident to Men, Women and Children; with Chymical Tinctures, Chymic • l Magiſteries, and Phyloſophical Secrets, of excellent Uſe and Concerncernment. Never before Printed.

A Pleaſant and Compendious Hiſtory of the firſt Inventers and Inſtituters of the moſt Famous Arts, Myſteries, Laws, Cuſtoms and Manners in the whole World. Together with many other Rarities and Remarkable things, Rarely known, and never before made publick. To which is added, Several Curious Inventions, peculiarly Attributed to England and Engliſh-men. The whole Work Alphabetically Digeſted, and very helpful to the Readers of Hiſtory. Price B • und One Shilling.

Or, The Boaſt of the Britiſh S ••
Containing a True and full Account • the Royal Navy of England, ſhewing whe • each Ship was Built, by whom, and when its Length, Breadth, Depth, Draught of Water, Tuns, the number of Men and Guns, both in Peace and War, at Home and Abroad. Together with every Man's Pay, from a Captain to a Cabin-Boy; truly Calculated and Ca •• up, for a Day, a Week, a Month, and a Kalendar Year, or 13 Months and a Day. Carefully Collected and Digeſted by a True Lover of the Seam • n, and of long Experience in the Practices of the N •• y and Admiralty. Price One Shilling.
